title: STAT 109: Introductory Biostatistics
text:
Quick Start

Course Schedule - Weekly schedule and course materials
Course Syllabus - Detailed course information and policies
Lectures - All course lectures organized by week
Assessments - Quizzes, exams, and projects
Resources - Textbook, R downloads, and reference materials

title: STAT 109: Introductory Biostatistics
text:
Course Overview
STAT 109: Introductory Biostatistics (4 units) introduces descriptive statistics, probability, random variables, distributions, confidence intervals, hypothesis testing, regression, and ANOVA with emphasis on applications in biological and natural resource sciences.
Lecture: Monday, Wednesday, Friday, 11:00–11:50 AM, BSS 166
Lab: Thursday (select one section: 9:00–10:50 AM, 11:00–12:50 PM, or 1:00–2:50 PM), FH 202
General Education: Lower Division GE Area 2 (Quantitative Reasoning)

title: STAT 109: Introductory Biostatistics
text:
Course Structure
Includes collaborative daily warm-ups, weekly programming labs, weekly quizzes, two midterms, and five portfolio ready projects. Optional final exam may replace one midterm grade.

title: STAT 109: Introductory Biostatistics
text:
Instructor Information
Instructor: Dr. Rosanna Overholser
Office: BSS 334
Email: rho3@humboldt.edu
Office Hours: Mondays 2-3pm, Wednesdays 12-12:50pm, Fridays 10-10:50am, or by appointment

title: Quiz 3
text:
These are practice problems covering:

Lectures 3–4: sample spaces, outcomes, events, and probability calculations when the outcomes are equally likely
Lecture 5: addition rule
Lab 2 (R code by hand): types, vectors, matrices, bracketing, length(), dim(), and basic for loops + simulation structure






Work without notes first; then check your answers. I’ll post my solutions to Lab 2 after the due date.
For R questions, write valid R code exactly as you would type it (by hand).
The in-class quiz in lab on Thursday will be created from these practice problems.







Consider the trial of rolling a single six-sided die one time.

Write the sample space \(S\).
Give one outcome.
Define an event \(A\) and list the outcomes in \(A\).





Suppose a trial has sample space \(S\) and two events \(A\) and \(B\).

In words, what does “\(A\) and \(B\)” mean?
In words, what does “\(A\) or \(B\)” mean?
In words, what does “not \(A\)” mean?





Write a one-sentence interpretation for each:

\(P(A) = 0.7\)
\(P(A \text{ and } B) = 0.2\)
\(P(\text{not } A) = 0.1\)








State the probability rule for an event \(A\) if the outcomes in \(S\) are equally likely:
\[
P(A) = \quad ?
\]
Be sure to define what \(|A|\) and \(|S|\) mean in words.



State the condition that must be true for the probability rule \(P(A) = |A|/|S|\) to be valid.




Suppose a fair coin is tossed two times.

List the sample space \(S\) so that all outcomes are equally likely.
Let \(A\) be the event “at least one tail.” List the outcomes in \(A\).
Compute \(P(A)\).





Suppose a fair die is rolled twice.

How many outcomes are in the sample space \(S\) written so that all outcomes are equally likely?
List the outcomes from \(S\) in the event \(C =\) “the sum is 11.”
Compute \(P(C)\).





Three babies are randomly returned to three mothers (assume all pairings are equally likely).

How many outcomes are in the sample space?
Let \(A\) be the event “all 3 mothers get the correct baby.” Compute \(P(A)\).
Let \(B\) be the event “none of the mothers get the correct baby.” Compute \(P(B)\)








State the Addition Rule for any two events \(A\) and \(B\).




A class has 65 students:

40 have backpacks
10 have hats
5 have both a backpack and a hat

Let \(A\) be the event a randomly selected student “has a backpack” and \(B\) be “has a hat.”

Compute \(P(A)\) and \(P(B)\).
Compute \(P(A \text{ and } B)\).
Use the addition rule to compute \(P(A \text{ or } B)\).





If \(P(\text{rains at least once in July}) = 0.91\), compute:
\[
P(\text{no rain in July})
\]




Suppose \(A\) and \(B\) are non-overlapping (mutually exclusive) events.

What does “non-overlapping” mean in words?
What does it imply about \(P(A \text{ and } B)\)?
Write the simplified formula for \(P(A \text{ or } B)\) in this case.








Write R code that:

creates x_num as the numeric value of 0,
creates x_int as an integer (use the L),
prints the class of each.





Write R code that:

creates a numeric vector v that contains the values 2, 4, 6, 8 and 10.
prints the length of v
creates a new vector called v_plus_one that is v with 1 added to each of it’s values.





Using v <- c(2, 4, 6, 8, 10), write R code for each:

the 3rd element
the 2nd through 4th elements
everything except the 3rd element
all elements greater than 5





Write R code that:

creates a 2x3 matrix m filled by column using 1:6,
prints the dimensions of m
extracts the value of m in the second row and first column
extracts the first row
extracts the second column





Write R code that uses a for loop to fill a vector named squares with the squares of 1 through 5:
Expected result for squares
[1]  1  4  9 16 25




Write R code to estimate the probability that a fair die roll is even using simulation:

simulate n <- 10000 die rolls using sample(1:6, size = n, replace = TRUE)
compute the estimated probability with mean(...)

Your code should create objects named n, rolls, and p_even.
